answer:
<p>There is some method to the madness. As a general rule, if a browser can interpret a date as an ISO-8601, it will. "2005-07-08" falls into this camp, and so it is parsed as UTC. "Jul 8, 2005" cannot, and so it is parsed in the local time.</p>

<p>See <a href="http://blog.dygraphs.com/2012/03/javascript-and-dates-what-mess.html">JavaScript and Dates, What a Mess!</a> for more.</p>

<p>While <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/a/2587398">CMS is correct</a> that passing strings into the parse method is generally unsafe, the new <a href="http://www.ecma-international.org/publications/files/ECMA-ST/ECMA-262.pdf" rel="nofollow noreferrer">ECMA-262 5th Edition</a> (aka ES5) specification in section 15.9.4.2 suggests that <code>Date.parse()</code> actually should handle ISO-formatted dates.  The old specification made no such claim.  Of course, old browsers and some current browsers still do not provide this ES5 functionality.</p>

<p>Your second example isn't wrong.  It is the specified date in UTC, as implied by <code>Date.prototype.toISOString()</code>, but is represented in your local timezone.</p>
data.title: Why does Date.parse give incorrect results?
